title: What is "Cognitio Dei Experientalis" in Christian Mysticism according to this text?
first_phrase: In this text, the author discusses the concept of the "cognitio Dei experientialis," or experimental knowledge of God, in Christian mysticism. It is essential for this knowledge to be in an "eccentric" (non-central) state, as indicated by the term "estasi" (ecstasy), which means "going out of oneself." The author argues that while the illuminative phase of this knowledge can be emotional rather than intellectual, the Christian devotional framework may not be helpful for guiding it. The text also explores the effects of the six gifts of the Holy Spirit according to Thomas Aquinas, which are related to the power of discovering substance and truth. The concluding 200 tokens delve into the in-depth contemplation and spiritual practices, involving passing through various realms and purifying the soul.

last_phrase: In conclusion, while the concept of the six gifts of the Holy Spirit may be seen as initiatory powers, it ultimately remains a theoretical framework. Similarly, the idea of gradual purification after death is no longer generally accepted by Catholic theologians. However, these doctrines can still offer valuable insights into the spiritual journey and the importance of cultivating an intimate relationship with God.
